name: altopth
params: class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3
body: |- wb(wceq(caltop(c0, c1), caltop(c2, c3)), wa(wceq(c0, c2), wceq(c1, c3)))

stmt.origin: mp2an(wb(wceq(caltop(c0, c1), caltop(c2, c3)), wa(wceq(c0, c2), wceq(c1, c3))), wcel(c0, universe), wcel(c1, universe))

|- wb(wceq(caltop(c0, c1), caltop(c2, c3)), wa(wceq(c0, c2), wceq(c1, c3)))
-| wcel(c0, universe)
-| wcel(c1, universe)

stmt.pretty: altopthg(c0, universe, c1, universe, c2, c3)

body.origin: |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, universe), wcel(c1, universe)), wb(wceq(caltop(c0, c1), caltop(c2, c3)), wa(wceq(c0, c2), wceq(c1, c3))))

comment: The alternate ordered pair theorem. If two alternate ordered pairs are equal, their first elements are equal and their second elements are equal. Note that ` C ` and ` D ` are not required to be a set due to a peculiarity of our specific ordered pair definition, as opposed to the regular ordered pairs used here, which (as in ~ opth ), requires ` D ` to be a set. (Contributed by Scott Fenton, 23-Mar-2012.)
